newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Winded Irish pound pauses for breath.
newsitem.headline: Winded Irish pound pauses for breath.

text.p: The Irish pound opened quietly on Friday, still licking its wounds after a sharp sell-off by offshore operators on Thursday, dealers said.

By 0935 GMT, the Irish pound was unchanged on closing levels at 0.8860 stg but recouped some losses against the mark trading at 2.6805/45 marks, having lost a pfennig on Thursday to close at 2.6760 marks.
"It has stabilised somewhat but there was sharp selling pressure from offshore yesterday," one currency dealer said.
He said selling interest was partially triggered by stering's rally and a belief that even if Ireland revalues the currency, it will still need to drop from current levels versus the mark.
"As sterling bounces back it produces levels in the mark/Irish, which is the focus of a lot of institutional investors, who then find it attractive to sell," the dealer said.
He said there was also some speculative play in Thursday's sell-off.

"There was speculative pressure as well from the offshore community on the belief that a revaluation will only produce maybe five to 10 percent change, bringing the middle band to a level that is still not as high as where we are in the mark/Irish at the moment," the dealer said.

Dealers said while the main selling pressure was in the mark/Irish, it was also impacting on sterling/Irish although the Irish unit was still off the lows of last week where it bottomed out at 87.30 stg.
Sterling's bounce on Thursday was triggered by comments by Gordon Brown who dispelled the theory that he was going to have an interim budget in November, the dealer said.
Brown said in a Times interview that he had no plans for a special autumn budget to attempt to brake consumer spending.
Dealers said local activity was likely to remain subdued ahead of Ireland's long weekend but direction will be dictated by international moves.
